title: After loss to Warren, Republican John Deaton announces another run for Senate
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: John Deaton, a Marine veteran and lawyer, announces his candidacy for Sen. Ed Markey's Massachusetts seat in 2026.
Deaton emphasizes his 'independent voice' focusing on issues like energy and housing prices as part of his campaign.
Deaton previously ran against Sen. Elizabeth Warren; Markey faces a primary challenge from Rep. Seth Moulton.

title: What will the Red Sox target this offseason? Craig Breslow maps out Boston’s priorities.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox aim to acquire a top pitcher to join Garrett Crochet for playoff readiness, possibly targeting free agents or trades.
Boston seeks to re-sign Alex Bregman and boost lineup power, with players like Kyle Schwarber or Pete Alonso as potential targets.
Craig Breslow emphasizes balancing immediate success with future planning, mindful of trade-offs to improve the 2026 roster.

title: Zdeno Chara’s 10 most memorable moments with the Bruins
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Zdeno Chara was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame, recognizing his impactful career as a dominant defenseman.
Chara captained the Boston Bruins for 14 seasons, leading them to a Stanley Cup victory after a 39-year drought.
His memorable moments include setting an NHL hardest shot record and playing the 2019 Stanley Cup Final with a broken jaw.

title: Bill Belichick reflects on ‘learning curve’ during first season coaching college football
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Bill Belichick reflects on learning coaching nuances in his first year leading UNC with a 4-5 record.
UNC needs two more wins to match last year's record, with crucial games against Wake Forest and Duke.
Belichick acknowledges adjustment challenges, noting improvements after early-season struggles and a mid-season losing streak.

title: Patriots have 15 players land on injury report, but get some good news
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: 15 players listed on the New England Patriots' injury report, including Austin Hooper who missed practice due to a concussion.
Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson were limited participants Monday, indicating potential improvement from hamstring and toe injuries.
The Patriots face a tight schedule with a Thursday game against the Jets after Sunday's win over the Buccaneers.

title: Georgia man allegedly stole millions in unclaimed Mass. property
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Shaka Stayman, 44, from Atlanta, is accused of stealing millions from Massachusetts' unclaimed property division.
He allegedly forged documents and filed false claims to obtain $1.1 million, with attempts to claim $2.2 million more.
Stayman faces 25 counts in court; held on $2 million bail, he is also awaiting federal sentencing in Alabama.

title: TreVeyon Henderson explained why he looked at the sideline during key TD run
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: TreVeyon Henderson looked to the sideline for guidance during a key touchdown run with under two minutes left.
Henderson scored despite receiving mixed signals, helping the Patriots secure a win against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.
The touchdown marked Henderson's most productive game, surpassing 100 yards and scoring multiple touchdowns for the first time.

title: Mason Lohrei is latest Bruins player to respond from a Marco Sturm benching
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mason Lohrei returned to the Bruins' lineup against Toronto after being benched for five games by coach Marco Sturm.
Lohrei contributed two assists in the Bruins' 5-3 win over the Maple Leafs, showcasing a strong performance.
Coach Marco Sturm's benchings have prompted strong responses from players like Lohrei, aiding Bruins' lineup competitiveness.

title: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Petitioners aiming to repeal recreational marijuana in Massachusetts are accused of misleading voters about their petitions.
Complaints allege petitioners misrepresent their initiative; however, organizers call the accusations 'baseless charges' amid rising signature counts.
Massachusetts Cannabis Business Association claims widespread 'organized voter fraud' by those collecting signatures to repeal marijuana legalization.

title: Massachusetts state payroll hits $9B in 2025 — UMass system dominates
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts state payroll reached $9.19 billion in 2025, a decrease from last year's $10.26 billion.
UMass employees held all top 15 highest-paid state employee positions, with Frank Martin earning $1.96 million.
The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority had the second-largest state payroll at $799.68 million, followed by the Trial Court at $574.67 million.
